Primary Field: South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission (South Africa |  |  |  |  |  |)
Name: South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission
Summary:
The Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) was a court-like restorative justice body assembled in South Africa after the end of apartheid in 1995. Witnesses who were identified as victims of gross human rights violations were invited to give statements about their experiences, and some were selected for public hearings. Perpetrators of violence could also give testimony and request amnesty from both civil and criminal prosecution.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truth_and_Reconciliation_Commission_(South_Africa)

Primary Field: Trial of Breyten Breytenbach (South Africa |  |  | Johannesburg |  |  |)
Name: Trial of Breyten Breytenbach
Summary: In 1975, Breyten Breytenbach, the anti-apartheid poet, was sent for trial in the Supreme Court in South Africa on charges carrying the death penalty. Breytenbach, at the time aged 36, was accused under the Terrorism and Anti-Communism Acts of helping to set up an illegal organization to promote armed struggle in South Africa intended to overthrow the white government.

Primary Field: Marriage to Mary Garman (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Marriage to Mary Garman
Summary: Mary Garman married South African poet Roy Campbell in 1924 in London, England.

Primary Field: US Athletes boycott Olympics, with support from SANROC (Dennis Brutus) (United States |  |  |  |  |  |)
Name: US Athletes boycott Olympics, with support from SANROC (Dennis Brutus)
Summary: By September 26, 1967, black American athletes were likely to boycott the 1968 Olympics in Mexico City in response to racist South African policies.

Primary Field: Degree Doctor of Letters by Diploma conferred to Léopold Sédar Senghor (England |  | Oxfordshire | Oxford |  |  |)
Name: Degree Doctor of Letters by Diploma conferred to Léopold Sédar Senghor
Summary: On October 26, 1973, the Chancellor of Oxford University, Harold Macmillan, granted a Doctor of Letters by Diploma to Léopold Sédar Senghor, president of Senegal. Senghor was the second head of an African state to receive such a degree.

Primary Field: Performance of "The Lion and the Jewel" by Wole Soyinka on the BBC Third Programme (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Performance of "The Lion and the Jewel" by Wole Soyinka on the BBC Third Programme
Summary: In May 1966, Wole Soyinka's play "The Lion and the Jewel" was featured on the BBC Third Programme.

Primary Field: Death of Foreign Minister of Malagasy Republic (Madagascar |  |  | Tananarive |  |  |)
Name: Death of Foreign Minister of Malagasy Republic
Summary: The Malagasy Republic's ambassador in London,  Jules Razafimbahiny, was called back to help fill the gap caused by the death of the Malagasy Foreign Minister, Dr. Albert Sylla, in an air crash in Madagascar in August 1967.

Primary Field: Nigerian Civil War (Nigeria |  |  | Enugu |  |  |)
Name: Nigerian Civil War
Summary:
The Nigerian Civil War (also known as the Biafran War and the Nigerian-Biafran War) was a civil war in Nigeria fought between the government of Nigeria and the secessionist state of Biafra from 6 July 1967 to 15 January 1970. Biafra represented nationalist aspirations of the Igbo people, whose leadership felt they could no longer coexist with the Northern-dominated federal government.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nigerian_Civil_War

Primary Field: Population Registration Act (South Africa |  |  | Cape Town |  |  |)
Name: Population Registration Act
Summary:
The Population Registration Act of 1950 required that each inhabitant of South Africa be classified and registered in accordance with his or her racial characteristics as part of the system of apartheid.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_Registration_Act,_1950

Primary Field: Arrest of Ken Saro-Wiwa (Nigeria |  |  | Port Harcourt |  |  |)
Name: Arrest of Ken Saro-Wiwa
Summary: On Monday, June 21, 1993 in Port Harcourt, poet Ken Saro-Wiwa was arrested and detained by Nigerian authorities but was released after a month.

Primary Field: First International Congress of Negro Writers and Artists (France |  |  | Paris |  |  |)
Name: First International Congress of Negro Writers and Artists
Summary:
The First International Congress of Black Writers and Artists, held from September 19-22, 1956 at the Sorbonne in Paris, was one of the most significant gatherings of black intellectuals during the twentieth century.

https://arcade.stanford.edu/content/women-and-1956-congress-black-writers-and-artists-paris

Primary Field: The South Bank Show ()
Name: The South Bank Show

Primary Field: International PEN Conference (England |  | Cambridgeshire | Cambridge |  |  |)
Name: International PEN Conference
Summary: At the four day International PEN Conference at Cambridge in England in 1988, the interdependence of academia and creative writing were discussed as the major theme. The conference drew about 150 members, including Geoffrey Haresnape, a South African poet and professor at the University of Cape Town.

Primary Field: Attempted Murder of Dennis Brutus (South Africa |  |  |  |  |  |)
Name: Attempted Murder of Dennis Brutus
Summary: In 1963 in South Africa, the South African police were suggested to have fired two shots at poet and weightlifting champion in a suggested attempted murder for his work protesting the racial discrimination in South African sport.

Primary Field: Conference of African Linguists (Germany |  |  | Cologne |  |  |)
Name: Conference of African Linguists
Summary: On October 1, 1982, the Conference of African Linguists commenced in Cologne, Germany.

Primary Field: Booker McConnell Prize for fiction Award ()
Name: Booker McConnell Prize for fiction Award
Summary: In 1983 in Cape Town, South Africa, the Booker McConnell prize for fiction was awarded to J. M. Coetzee for "Life and Times of Michael K," published by Secker and Warburg.

Primary Field: "Drum," African Magazine Begins (South Africa |  |  | Johannesburg |  |  |)
Name: "Drum," African Magazine Begins
Summary:
"Drum," initially titled "African Drum," was created by author Bob Crisp in 1951. "Drum" was a South African family magazine that targeted black readers and covered news and entertainment. "Drum" is most noted for its reporting in the 1950s and 60s on life in townships under apartheid. By 1965, "Drum" had faded in popularity, but was revived in 1968, and remains as the sixth largest magazine in South Africa.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drum_(South_African_magazine)"

Primary Field: Sharpeville Massacre (South Africa |  | Sharpeville | Vereeniging |  |  |)
Name: Sharpeville Massacre
Summary:
The Sharpeville massacre occurred on March 21, 1960, at the police station in the South African township of Sharpeville in Transvaal. After a day of demonstrations against "pass laws," a crowd of about 7,000 protesters went to the police station. The South African Police opened fire on the crowd, killing 69 people and injuring 180 others

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharpeville_massacre

Primary Field: Defiance Campaign  against Unjust Laws (South Africa |  |  | Bloemfontein |  |  |)
Name: Defiance Campaign  against Unjust Laws
Summary:
The Defiance Campaign against Unjust Laws was presented by the African National Congress (ANC) at a conference held in Bloemfontein, South Africa in December 1951. The Defiance Campaign was launched on the anniversary of the National Day of Protest, 26 June 1952. In major South African cities, people and organizations performed acts of defiance and civil disobedience.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defiance_Campaign

Primary Field: Building of the memorial, Mashu Campbell Bantu Museum (South Africa |  |  | KwaZulu-Natal |  |  |)
Name: Building of the memorial, Mashu Campbell Bantu Museum
Summary: In 1957, Sir Shane Leslie returned an ivory bracelet once worn by Shaka, the Zulu king, to the Zulu nation in Natal to be placed in a national museum in honor of Sir Marshall Campbell. Roy Campbell, the South African poet, is a member of the same family.

Primary Field: Retirement of Léopold Sédar Senghor (Senegal |  |  | Dakar |  |  |)
Name: Retirement of Léopold Sédar Senghor
Summary: President Leopold Sedar Senghor, 74, of Senegal stepped down on December 31, 1980, after 20 years in office. He was replaced by Mr. Abdou Diouf, who had been his Prime Minister for the past 10 years.

Primary Field: Election of Léopold Sédar Senghor, September 1960 (Senegal |  |  | Dakar |  |  |)
Name: Election of Léopold Sédar Senghor, September 1960
Summary: Leopold Senghor, poet and statesman, was today elected unanimously as first President of the Senegalese Republic on September 5, 1960.

Primary Field: University of Western Cape closed, student demonstrations (South Africa |  |  | Cape Town |  |  |)
Name: University of Western Cape closed, student demonstrations
Summary: On June 21, 1973, Adam Small, one of South Africa's leading intellectuals, resigned his teaching post at the  University of the Western Cape in Cape Town, South Africa. The University had been closed since June 11 following student demonstrations against alleged restrictive rules and white domination in running the institution.

Primary Field: South Africa expelled from Olympics Games (Netherlands |  |  | Amsterdam |  |  |)
Name: South Africa expelled from Olympics Games
Summary: South Africa were expelled from the Olympic movement on May 15 1970 of the International Olympic Committee congress on grounds of discriminatory processes in athletics. The voting was 35 for withdrawing recognition to 28 against, with three abstentions. The president of SANROC, Dennis Brutus welcomed the decision.

Primary Field: Commonwealth Arts Festival 1965 (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Commonwealth Arts Festival 1965
Summary: Over three weeks in 1965, the UK hosted visual artists, musicians, dancers, poets, and writers in a festival to "celebrate" their national cultures. The nations invited to attend were those considered part of the greater British Commonwealth of colonial nations. Wole Soyinka's play "The Road" was considered a highlight of the festival.

Primary Field: 10 Year Commemoration of Roy Campbell (Portugal |  |  | Lisbon |  |  |)
Name: 10 Year Commemoration of Roy Campbell
Summary:
Monday, April 24, 1967 marked the ten year anniversary of the passing of poet Roy Campbell. Campbell passed away in a motor accident in Lisbon. At a ten year commemoration, Mr. Francois Viljoen, the South African Ambassador in Lisbon, laid a wreath on the grave of Roy Campbell.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roy_Campbell_(poet)#Death"

Primary Field: Malagasy Army destroys dojo (Madagascar |  |  |  |  |  |)
Name: Malagasy Army destroys dojo
Summary: In 1985 in Madagascar, there was a rumor that an armored division of the Malagasy Army had been called in to destroy the dojo of an intransigent karate sect which had been terrorizing peaceable tourists.

Primary Field: Rabearivelo's suicide (Madagascar |  |  |  |  |  |)
Name: Rabearivelo's suicide
Summary: In 1937, Jean-Joseph Rabearivelo, Malagasy and French poet, completed suicide.

Primary Field: Whitbread Book Awards Announcement (England |  |  |  |  |  |)
Name: Whitbread Book Awards Announcement
Summary: On the radio in England in 1999, Richard Coles talks to leading South African poet and journalist Antjie Krog; plus the announcement of the Whitbread Book Awards.

Primary Field: Poetry International (England |  |  | London |  | Queen Elizabeth Hall |)
Name: Poetry International
Summary: The sixth Poetry International occurred from June 25 to June 30 1973. It was divided between the Queen Elizabeth Hall and the Institute of Contemporary Arts. Poetry International at the time had presented more than 50 poets from 19 countries, and in 1973 year it had its first South African, Oswald Mtshali.

Primary Field: 60th Birthday of William Plomer, President of the Poetry Society (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: 60th Birthday of William Plomer, President of the Poetry Society
Summary: On February 4, 1969, at a Poetry Gala in London, an evening of poetry recitals occurred in celebration of William Plomer's 60th birthday. He served as the President of the Poetry Society.

Primary Field: Release of Breyten Breytenbach (South Africa |  |  | Johannesburg |  |  |)
Name: Release of Breyten Breytenbach
Summary: In 1982, Breyten Breytenbach, South African Afrikaans poet, was released from prison after serving seven of the nine years to which he was sentenced in 1975 for promoting the aims of the banned African National Congress (ANC).

Primary Field: Secession of Biafra (Nigeria |  |  | Nsukka |  |  |)
Name: Secession of Biafra
Summary:
Biafra, officially the Republic of Biafra, was a state in West Africa that existed from May 1967 to January 1970. It was made up of the states in the Eastern Region of Nigeria. Biafra's declaration of independence from Nigeria resulted in civil war between Biafra and Nigeria.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biafra

Primary Field: Voluntary Exile of Wole Soyinka (England |  |  | Leeds |  |  |)
Name: Voluntary Exile of Wole Soyinka
Summary: In April 1971, concerned about the political situation in Nigeria, Soyinka resigned from his duties at the University in Ibadan, and began years of voluntary exile.

Primary Field: Léopold Sédar Senghor conferred honorary degree at Harvard University (United States | Massachusetts |  | Cambridge |  |  |)
Name: Léopold Sédar Senghor conferred honorary degree at Harvard University
Summary: On June 19, 1971, two writers involved in politics received honorary degrees at Harvard University: Alan Paton, novelist and leader of the South African Liberal Party, and Leopold Sedar Senghor, poet and President of Senegal.

Primary Field: Royal Colonial Institute, Meeting (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Royal Colonial Institute, Meeting
Summary: On January 23, 1918, a meeting of the Royal Colonial Institute occurred wherein Sir Herbert Warren read a paper on overseas poetry, including that of Cullen Gouldsbury and Rev. Arthur Shearley Cripps.

Primary Field: Kofi Awoonor's imprisonment  ()
Name: Kofi Awoonor's imprisonment
Summary: He was imprisoned for harboring a subversive on December 31, 1975, amid rumors of a possible coup.

Primary Field: Death of Charles Eglington (South Africa |  |  | Johannesburg |  |  |)
Name: Death of Charles Eglington
Summary: Charles Eglington, the South African writer and poet was found hanged at his home in Johannesburg in 1972. He was 52.

Primary Field: Imprisonment of Wole Soyinka (Nigeria |  |  | Enugu |  |  |)
Name: Imprisonment of Wole Soyinka
Summary: Following the military coup of January 1966, playwright and poet Wole Soyinka secretly and unofficially met with the military governor of Biafra in August 1967. As a result, he was imprisoned for 22 months as the civil war ensued between the Federal Government of Nigeria and the Biafrans. In October 1969, when the civil war came to an end, amnesty was proclaimed, and Soyinka and other political prisoners were freed.

Primary Field: Protests in Nigeria, 2010 (Nigeria |  |  |  |  |  |)
Name: Protests in Nigeria, 2010
Summary: On January 13, 2010, Wole Soyinka joined a group of protesters in Nigeria in Abuja.

Primary Field: Withdrawal of US Ambassador in Tananarive (Madagascar |  |  | Tananarive |  |  |)
Name: Withdrawal of US Ambassador in Tananarive
Summary: On June 28, 1971, The State Department of the United States announced that it was withdrawing its ambassador in Tananarive as a protest at accusations that the embassy had interfered in Malagasy internal affairs. Jacques Rabemananjara, the Malagasy Foreign Minister, said that his country still wanted good relations with the United States.

Primary Field: Wole Soyinka's passport impounded (Nigeria |  |  | Lagos |  |  |)
Name: Wole Soyinka's passport impounded
Summary: The passport of Mr. Wole Soyinka, the Nigerian playwright, was impounded by security officials at Ikeja airport on March 21, 1971.

Primary Field: Release of Wole Soyinka (Nigeria |  |  | Lagos |  |  |)
Name: Release of Wole Soyinka
Summary: On October 9, 1969, Wole Soyinka, the Nigerian playwright, was released from prison following his arrest and imprisonment for meeting with the military governor from the seceded Biafra in 1966.

Primary Field: Arrest of Wole Soyinka in August 1967 (Nigeria |  |  | Ibadan |  |  |)
Name: Arrest of Wole Soyinka in August 1967
Summary: In August of 1967, poet and playwright Wole Soyinka was imprisoned in Nigeria for signing a letter to a Nigerian newspaper proposing a truce to the conflict with the seceded territory of Biafra.

Primary Field: Release of Wole Soyinka in October 1967 (Nigeria |  |  | Lagos |  |  |)
Name: Release of Wole Soyinka in October 1967
Summary: In October of 1967, poet and playwright Wole Soyinka was released from his detainment for his involvement in promoting peace between the territory of Biafra and Nigeria.

Primary Field: Ken Saro-Wiwa's execution (Nigeria |  |  | Port Harcourt |  |  |)
Name: Ken Saro-Wiwa's execution
Summary:
On 21 May 1994, four Ogoni chiefs were murdered. Saro-Wiwa was arrested and accused of incitement to them. He denied the charges but was imprisoned for over a year before being found guilty and sentenced to death by a specially convened tribunal. On 10 November 1995, Saro-Wiwa and the rest of the Ogoni Nine were taken to a prison in Port Harcourt and executed by hanging.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ken_Saro-Wiwa

Primary Field: The "Big Sleep": Nigerian Economic Recession (Nigeria |  |  |  |  |  |)
Name: The "Big Sleep": Nigerian Economic Recession
Summary: The "Big Sleep" of literary works/publishing occurred during the Nigerian recession of the 1980s. Book sales fell, and foreign publishers reduced their investment in literature, and publishing ground to a halt.

Primary Field: Mbari Club in Ibadan (Nigeria |  |  | Ibadan |  |  |)
Name: Mbari Club in Ibadan
Summary: A club of intellectuals and artists in Nigeria; part of the "Ibadan Renaissance."

Primary Field: Performance of "The Road" by Wole Soyinka (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Performance of "The Road" by Wole Soyinka
Summary: On September 13, 1965, the Negro Theatre Workshop presented a special charity preview of "The Road" by Wole Soyinka at Theatre Royal, Stratford East.

Primary Field: Acquittal of Wole Soyinka (Nigeria |  |  | Lagos |  |  |)
Name: Acquittal of Wole Soyinka
Summary: In Lagos, Nigeria, on December 21 1965, Wole Soyinka, who had been standing trial on a charge of robbery, was acquitted by Mr. Justice Kayode Eso, who suggested there was a material conflict in the evidence of the prosecution witnesses. Soyinka had claimed he was not in Ibadan at the time of the crime.

Primary Field: Death of Okot p'Bitek  (Uganda |  |  | Kampala |  |  |)
Name: Death of Okot p'Bitek
Summary: Okot p'Bitek, a Ugandan poet, died on July 19, 1982 in Kampala, Uganda.

Primary Field: Death of F. C. Slater (South Africa |  |  | Cape Town |  |  |)
Name: Death of F. C. Slater
Summary: Francis Carey Slater, the South African poet, died in 1958 at the age of 84 in Cape Town, South Africa.

Primary Field: Arrests under the Terrorism Act (South Africa |  |  | Cape Town |  |  |)
Name: Arrests under the Terrorism Act
Summary: In Cape Town, South Africa, on September  16, 1975, four whites and an African were detained under the Terrorism Act by South African security police. These arrests were connected with the detention of Breyten Breytenbach, an Afrikaner poet, weeks prior.

Primary Field: Léopold Sédar Senghor visits the Queen of England (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Léopold Sédar Senghor visits the Queen of England
Summary: President Senghor of Senegal visited London to speak with the Queen of England in October of 1961.

Primary Field: Performance of "The Lion and the Jewel" by Wole Soyinka. (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Performance of "The Lion and the Jewel" by Wole Soyinka.
Summary: On December 12, 1966, Wole Soyinka's play "The Lion and the Jewel" was performed at the Royal Court Theatre in London. The play's opening was delayed due to illness, with its original opening date December 8.

Primary Field: Wole Soyinka appointed professor of comparative literature at the University of Ife (Nigeria |  |  | Lagos |  |  |)
Name: Wole Soyinka appointed professor of comparative literature at the University of Ife
Summary: In 1976 after a period of exile in Ghana, Wole Soyinka, the Nigerian playwright and poet, returned to Nigeria and was appointed professor of comparative literature at the University of Ife.

Primary Field: Zimbabwe International Book Fair (Zimbabwe |  |  | Harare |  |  |)
Name: Zimbabwe International Book Fair
Summary: Known as Africa's largest book event, the annual International Book Fair had a significant falling off rate in the year 2000 due to unrest and economic crisis in Zimbabwe.

Primary Field: Zimbabwe Economic Crisis (Zimbabwe |  |  | Harare |  |  |)
Name: Zimbabwe Economic Crisis
Summary: Zimbabwe began experiencing a period of considerable political and economic upheaval in 1999. Opposition to President Mugabe and the ZANU-PF government grew considerably after the mid-1990s in part due to worsening economic and human rights conditions.

Primary Field: World Festival of Negro Arts, 1974 (Nigeria |  |  | Lagos |  |  |)
Name: World Festival of Negro Arts, 1974
Summary: In 1974, Nigeria hosted the second World Festival of Negro Arts.

Primary Field: Race discrimination on Panorama, BBC programme (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Race discrimination on Panorama, BBC programme
Summary: The Prime Minister and six other men were named in a complaint laid at Bow Street police station on April 30, 1970, under the 1965 Race Relations Act. Mr. Peter Tombs, of Evans Road, Eynsham. Oxfordshire, a writer, said statements inciting unlawful race discrimination had been made on the B.B.C.'s Panorama programme by Mr. Wilson, Mr. John Arlott, Mr. Peter Hain, Mr. Jeffrey Crawford, the Bishop of Woolwich, the Right Rev. David Sheppard, Mr. Dennis Brutus and Mr John Darragh. [From Excerpt of text]

Primary Field: Arrest of Breyten Breytenbach (South Africa |  |  | Johannesburg |  |  |)
Name: Arrest of Breyten Breytenbach
Summary: In 1975 in Johannesburg, South Africa, Breyten Breytenbach, the jailed Afrikaans poet, had offered to infiltrate the South African Communist Party in exchange for his early release from prison. At that time, Breytenbach was already serving a nine-year prison sentence.

Primary Field: Imprisonment of Breyten Breytenbach (South Africa |  |  | Johannesburg |  |  |)
Name: Imprisonment of Breyten Breytenbach
Summary:
On an illegal trip to South Africa in 1975, Afrikaans poet Breyten Breytenbach was arrested and sentenced to nine years' imprisonment for high treason. Released in 1982 as a result of international protests, he returned to Paris and obtained French citizenship.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breyten_Breytenbach

Primary Field: In Conversation: Lunchtime Literary Event with Ama Ata Aidoo (England |  |  | London |  | Institute for Contemporary Arts |)
Name: In Conversation: Lunchtime Literary Event with Ama Ata Aidoo
Summary: Ghanaian writer Ama Ata Aidoo joins Margaret Busby in a discussion about her latest novel, Changes: A love story at the ICA on April 10th, 1991.

Primary Field: Nigerian Election 2011 (Nigeria |  |  | Lagos |  |  |)
Name: Nigerian Election 2011
Summary:
Parliamentary elections were held in Nigeria on 9 April 2011. The incumbent People's Democratic Party was running against the Action Congress of Nigeria and the Congress for Progressive Change.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Nigerian_parliamentary_election

Primary Field: Performance of "The Trials of Brother Jero" at the Hampstead Theatre Club (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Performance of "The Trials of Brother Jero" at the Hampstead Theatre Club
Summary: On June 29, 1966, Wole Soyinka's play "The Trials of Brother Jero" was performed at the Hampstead Theatre Club in London by an African company from the Transcription Centre Theatre Workshop.

Primary Field: Ghana cabinet reshuffle (Ghana |  |  | Accra |  |  |)
Name: Ghana cabinet reshuffle
Summary: In 1983, two cabinet ministers were dismissed: both Johnny Hansen, Labour and Welfare, and Ama Ata Aidoo, Education. They were replaced by Ato Austin and U. C. Dadson.

Primary Field: Conference of the English Academy of Southern Africa at Rhodes University (South Africa |  |  | Grahamstown |  |  |)
Name: Conference of the English Academy of Southern Africa at Rhodes University
Summary: The Conference of The English Academy of Southern Africa was held at Rhodes University in Grahamstown in July 1969 and its theme was South African writing in English.

Primary Field: Conference on the medieval Manding Empire of Mali (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Conference on the medieval Manding Empire of Mali
Summary: The Conference on the Medieval Manding Empire of Mali occurred during June of 1972 in London. African scholars, including Leopold Senghor, poet and Senegal's President, were in assembly.

Primary Field: Death of Christopher Okigbo (Nigeria |  |  | Nsukka |  |  |)
Name: Death of Christopher Okigbo
Summary: On September 18, 1967, Christopher Okigbo, Nigerian poet, was killed during a battle with the federal Nigerian army in the town of Nsukka. Okigbo was fighting on behalf of the seceded territory of Biafra in Nigeria.

Primary Field: International Conference on Human Rights (France |  |  | Paris |  |  |)
Name: International Conference on Human Rights
Summary: A two-day international conference on human rights occurred in Paris, France on May 30, 1985. The conference included the South African poet Breyten Breytenbach.

Primary Field: Economic agreement with Malagasy Republic (Madagascar |  |  | Tananarive |  |  |)
Name: Economic agreement with Malagasy Republic
Summary: A South African delegation arrived in Tananarive on November 11, 1970 to sign an economic agreement with the Malagasy Republic and for talks with Government leaders. Under the agreement South Africa will lend Madagascar the equivalent of 1,350,000--repayable over 25 years--to develop its tourist industry.

Primary Field: ICA Special Poetry Reading (England |  |  | London |  | Nash House |)
Name: ICA Special Poetry Reading
Summary: On July 1970, an ICA Special poetry reading was held featuring Janos Pilinszky, Ted Hughes, Carolyn Kizer, and Dennis Brutus at the Nash House.

Primary Field: BBC Arts and Africa Poetry Award (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: BBC Arts and Africa Poetry Award
Summary: In 1988 in London, Kojo Laing, African poet, received the BBC Arts and Africa Poetry Award for his collection "Godhorse."

Primary Field: Death of Sheik Benguedda El Hadj Belarbi (Algeria |  |  | Mazouna |  |  |)
Name: Death of Sheik Benguedda El Hadj Belarbi
Summary: The muslim poet Sheik Benguedda El Hadj Belarbi died on January 12, 1932 in Mazouna, Algeria.

Primary Field: Performance of "Death and the King's Horseman" at the National Theatre, March 2009 (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Performance of "Death and the King's Horseman" at the National Theatre, March 2009
Summary: On March 28, 2009, Wole Soyinka's play "Death and the King's Horseman" was performed at the National Theatre in London. The 1975 drama tells the story of Elesin, the horseman of a local chief in Oyo, Nigeria, who, when his chief dies, is supposed to follow him into the afterlife.

Primary Field: Performance of "Death and the King's Horseman" at the National Theatre, April 2009 (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Performance of "Death and the King's Horseman" at the National Theatre, April 2009
Summary: On April 4. 2009, Wole Soyinka's play "Death and the King's Horseman" was performed at the National Theatre in London. The 1975 drama tells the story of Elesin, the horseman of a local chief in Oyo, Nigeria, who, when his chief dies, is supposed to follow him into the afterlife.

Primary Field: Boycott of Olympic Games, 1976, Canada (Canada |  |  | Montreal |  |  |)
Name: Boycott of Olympic Games, 1976, Canada
Summary: In 1976 in Canada, Dennis Brutus, alongside SANROC, called for the boycott of the 1976 Summer Olympic Games in Montreal. Brutus and SANROC cite the racism inherent in South African policies for selecting only white athletes as the reason for requesting countries to boycott participation in the games.

Primary Field: Boycott of Olympic Games, 1976, South Africa (South Africa |  |  |  |  |  |)
Name: Boycott of Olympic Games, 1976, South Africa
Summary: In 1976 in Canada, Dennis Brutus, alongside SANROC, called for the boycott of the 1976 Summer Olympic Games in Montreal. Brutus and SANROC cite the racism inherent in South African policies for selecting only white athletes as the reason for requesting countries to boycott participation in the games.

Primary Field: Protest on behalf of Wole Soyinka's arrest (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Protest on behalf of Wole Soyinka's arrest
Summary: On November 27, 1968, following Wole Soyinka's arrest in 1967, a group of demonstrators with "Free Soyinka" banners protested his imprisonment outside of the Mercury in London.

Primary Field: Protest Demonstration at Ibadan University (Nigeria |  |  | Ibadan |  |  |)
Name: Protest Demonstration at Ibadan University
Summary: On October 18, 1965, a class occurred between police and undergraduates at Ibadan University in Nigeria. The protest demonstration at Ibadan University was in response to the the outcome of the regional elections. In Lagos market, women were dispersed by police with tear gas while on a protest march to the Prime Minister's residence. Police in Ibadan declared Mr. Wole Soyinka, a Nigerian playwright and poet, to be a wanted person.

Primary Field: Detention/Release of Jack Mapanje (Malawi |  |  |  |  |  |)
Name: Detention/Release of Jack Mapanje
Summary: Jack Mapanje, Malawi's best-known poet, was released in May 1990 after three-and-a-half years' detention by the Malawi government without charge or trial.

Primary Field: Boycott of British Commonwealth Games (SANROC) (Scotland |  |  | Edinburgh |  |  |)
Name: Boycott of British Commonwealth Games (SANROC)
Summary: On April 24, 1970 in England, Dennis Brutus, along with SANROC, led a mass boycott of the British Commonwealth Games in Edinburgh for racism in the South African sport for refusing to allow nonwhite athletes.

Primary Field: Commonwealth Education Conference (India |  |  | Delhi |  |  |)
Name: Commonwealth Education Conference
Summary: The Commonwealth Education Conference, held in Delhi in January of 1962, was a meeting of educational ministers from colonial nations of the UK who were seeking additional education and training in order to increase the educational level of their nation. The Conference in 1962 specifically considered books and their publishing in the English language.

Primary Field: Execution of Benjamin Moloise (South Africa |  |  | Johannesburg |  |  |)
Name: Execution of Benjamin Moloise
Summary:
Benjamin Moloise, a black South African poet, was convicted to capital punishment by the apartheid regime of South Africa for allegedly murdering a policeman in 1982. The African National Congress claimed responsibility for the murder and repudiated the claim that Moloise was involved, but Moloise was hanged on 18 October 1985 at the Pretoria Central Prison despite worldwide pleas for clemency.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benjamin_Moloise

Primary Field: The Politics of Exile, Conference (England |  |  | London |  | Institute for Contemporary Arts. |)
Name: The Politics of Exile, Conference
Summary: Beginning April 25, 1987 in London, The Politics of Exile Conference, organized by the Third World Foundation and South magazine at the Institute for Contemporary Arts, occurred. It featured writers and intellectuals who spoke about the Latin American, African, Middle-Eastern, South Asian, and African experiences of exile.

Primary Field: Nobel Prize for Literature awarded to Wole Soyinka (Nigeria |  |  |  |  |  |)
Name: Nobel Prize for Literature awarded to Wole Soyinka
Summary: The main literary award winners of 1986 were as follows: the Nobel Prize for Literature, Wole Soyinka of Nigeria; the Booker Prize, Kingsley Amis; the Prix Goncourt, Michel Host; the Ritz Paris Hemingway Award, Marguerite Duras.

Primary Field: John Whiting Award to Wole Soyinka (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: John Whiting Award to Wole Soyinka
Summary: Lord Goodman, chairman of the Arts Council, presented the John Whiting Award in 1967 to playwright Wole Soyinka. This award was given to British or Commonwealth playwrights for a play or plays, either read in script form or seen in production during the year, which show a new and distinctive development in dramatic writing.

Primary Field: Dennis Brutus protests the Olympics (SANROC), February 1970, London (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Dennis Brutus protests the Olympics (SANROC), February 1970, London
Summary: Dennis Brutus protests South Africa's involvement in sports internationally with SANROC. He works to bring attention to the state of South Africa under apartheid.

Primary Field: Dennis Brutus protests the Olympics (SANROC), 1969, South Africa (South Africa |  |  |  |  |  |)
Name: Dennis Brutus protests the Olympics (SANROC), 1969, South Africa
Summary: Critics of apartheid suggest that the South African cricket team should not be allowed to perform in the 1970 South African Tour of England (which was, indeed, canceled). In 1962, the "South African non-racial Open Committee for Olympic Sports"--SANROC--was formed. Headed by Dennis Brutus, this group organized multiple boycotts and protests against South Africa's participation in international sport competitions.

Primary Field: Dennis Brutus protests the Olympics (SANROC), May 1970, London (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Dennis Brutus protests the Olympics (SANROC), May 1970, London
Summary: Dennis Brutus protests South Africa's involvement in sports internationally with SANROC. He works to bring attention to the state of South Africa under apartheid.

Primary Field: Dennis Brutus protests the Olympics (SANROC), 1977, London (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Dennis Brutus protests the Olympics (SANROC), 1977, London
Summary: Dennis Brutus, on behalf of SANROC, flew into London in June of 1977 in order to protest Wimbledon, as he similarly organized the walkout at the Montreal Olympics in 1976.  Brutus flew into London with a threat that the Centre Court could be sabotaged if white South Africans are allowed to play.

Primary Field: Dennis Brutus protests the Olympics (SANROC), 1969, London (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Dennis Brutus protests the Olympics (SANROC), 1969, London
Summary: Dennis Brutus protests South Africa's involvement in sports internationally with SANROC. He works to bring attention to the state of South Africa under apartheid.

Primary Field: Dennis Brutus protests the Olympics (SANROC), 1976, Montreal (Canada |  |  | Montreal |  |  |)
Name: Dennis Brutus protests the Olympics (SANROC), 1976, Montreal
Summary: Dennis Brutus organized a mass boycott/protest of South Africa's participation in the 1976 Montreal Olympics with SANROC, the South African Non-Racial Open Committee.

Primary Field: Dennis Brutus protests the Olympics (SANROC), 1971, London (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Dennis Brutus protests the Olympics (SANROC), 1971, London
Summary: A non-white sports committee was formed to work alongside the white South African Olympic and National Games Association towards South Africa's fight for re-entry to the Olympics. Dennis Brutus spoke out against this move, suggesting that it was a "blow" to black South Africans who want multi-racial sports.

Primary Field: Performance of "Anowa" at the Gate Theatre (Ireland |  |  | Dublin |  |  |)
Name: Performance of "Anowa" at the Gate Theatre
Summary: Ama Ata Aidoo's play "Anowa" is performed at the Gate Theatre as part of a season of women's theatre sponsored by NatWest.

Primary Field: Arrest of Pitika Ntuli (Swaziland |  |  |  |  |  |)
Name: Arrest of Pitika Ntuli
Summary: On April 7, 1978, Pitika Ntuli, a South African poet and sculptor living in exile in Swaziland, was arrested and detained by Swazi authorities under anti-terrorism law. He was not charged with any offense and was held for a year on death row as a political prisoner in a Swaziland jail. Once released, he fled to England, where he lived for 18 years.

Primary Field: Performance of "The Invention" by Wole Soyinka (England |  |  | London |  |  |)
Name: Performance of "The Invention" by Wole Soyinka
Summary: On November 1, 1959, Wole Soyinka's play "The Invention" was performed at the Royal Court in London.

Primary Field: African Literature: What Shall We Read? (England |  |  | London |  | Commonwealth Institute |)
Name: African Literature: What Shall We Read?
Summary: On Friday, April 12 to Saturday, April 13, 1991, a conference was held at the Commonwealth Institute in London to celebrate and discuss African Literature. The event included participants such as Ama Ata Aidoo, Cyprian Ekwensi, Chenjerai Hove, Aminata Sow-Fall.

Primary Field: Christopher Okigbo Nigerian Arms Deal (Nigeria |  |  |  |  |  |)
Name: Christopher Okigbo Nigerian Arms Deal
Summary: On October 30, 1966, Chritopher Okigbo, a poet from Eastern Nigeria, planned the deal with a French ex-policeman, Paul Favier to transport 1,007 sub-machine guns to defend the Ibo against the ravages of the Hausa tribesmen from Northern Nigeria.

Primary Field: Arrest and Imprisonment of Dennis Brutus (South Africa |  |  | Johannesburg |  |  |)
Name: Arrest and Imprisonment of Dennis Brutus
Summary: In Johannesburg, South Africa, on January 9, 1964, Dennis Brutus, president of SANROC, was sentenced to eighteen months of imprisonment on four charges of contravening a banning order and one of escaping from custody.

Primary Field: Death of Roy Campbell (Portugal |  |  | Lisbon |  | Setubal |)
Name: Death of Roy Campbell
Summary: Roy Campbell, a South African poet, was killed in a car accident in near Setubal, Portugal on April 23, 1957. His wife was taken to the hospital but survived.

Primary Field: Death of Léopold Sédar Senghor (France |  |  | Verson |  |  |)
Name: Death of Léopold Sédar Senghor
Summary: Léopold Sédar Senghor, poet and Senegal's President for two decades, died on December 20, 2001.

Primary Field: Veldsinger's Club (South Africa |  |  | Johannesburg |  |  |)
Name: Veldsinger's Club
Summary: The Veldsinger's Club was a small company of South Africans living in Johannesburg who enjoyed poetry. They published a small collection of verses written by the members. Olive Schreiner writes the forward to this work.

Primary Field: World Festival of Negro Arts, 1966 (Nigeria |  |  | Lagos |  |  |)
Name: World Festival of Negro Arts, 1966
Summary: In 1966, Nigeria hosted the first World Festival of Negro Arts.
